body:
Think about it:

Rowan is going to find Aelin only for her to look at him with warped recognitionin in her eyes as she asks “Are you the prince who loved the princess?”

blog.title: Torture and Interior Design
blog.description:
Owned and managed by Irving Braxiatel himself, the Braxiatel Collection is arguably the finest and most extensive collection in the known universe. 'Collection of what?' is an invalid question. It is a collection of everything.
Greetings, my name is April and this is my little Collection of everything.
My blog has the official approval of Miles Richardson. (15/09/2016).
Previously known as songofgallifrey.

tags: a court of thorns and roses
a court of mist and fury
a court of wings and ruin
body:
Story of my life

*bookstagram account posts a pic*

Me: I’m reading this next

*a publisher’s account posts a pic*

Me: Ooh I will definitely start this now

*friend suggests something*

Me: Next on my tbr, I swear!

Me: *stares at pile of unread books already in bookshelf* *stares at the three newly bought books*

Me: Shit. *Decides to reread SJM*

Marie, 29, Blogger, Schizotypal, addicted to Twitter, Photoshop and Books. A giant music 

enthusiast. Main fandoms: Teen Wolf, Tokio Hotel, One Direction, 5SOS, Criminal Minds, Shadowhunters. Other interests include Graphic Design, Photography, Cats, Bunnies and a whole lot of other stuff.

title: Drunk Book Tag
body:
Regitze fra Bookish Love Affair har tagget mig i dette vældig underholdende tag. Jeg må indrømme det ikke er et nemt tag at besvare, men sjovt var det. Hvis du læser dette og ønsker at lave tagget, så gør det endelig og link mig også gerne til svarene i en kommentar.

1. Wine Coolers: You’re 16 and you finally managed to sneak one of your mom’s Smirnoff Ices. What is one of your most guilty…

tags: a court of frost and starlight
summary: A Court of Frost & Starlight by Sarah J. Maas "'I think my heart knew you were mine long before I ever realized it.'" Year Read:...
body:
A Court of Frost & Starlight by Sarah J. Maas

“‘I think my heart knew you were mine long before I ever realized it.’”

Year Read: 2018

Rating: 4/5

Context: I’ve seen almost nothing but negative reviews for this novella, and it’s pretty easy to see what happened. Fans were expecting a novel-quality plot to hold them over until the next book, and that’s one hundred percent not what this is. Much as I don’t like researching a book before I read it, it’s better to go into this one with eyes open. A Court of Frost & Starlight is a sweet, fluffy winter novella that shows the Night Court basically hanging out, preparing for a holiday, and managing their respective traumas from the previous series.

If you’re one of those people who could watch your favorite characters do laundry and be happy about it, this is for you. If you’re plot-driven, skip this one. I don’t feel that it’s a shameless money-grab (although the price is steep for so few pages– but then, it looks so lovely on the shelf with the others) so much as a labor of love, and that works better for some people than others. There are spoilers ahead for A Court of Thorns & Roses, A Court of Mist & Fury, and A Court of Wings and Ruin.

About: Solstice, a winter Christmas-like fae holiday, is approaching, and Feyre has no idea what to get for her family, particularly her difficult-to-shop-for mate. Worse, she’s not sure how she’s going to convince an isolated Nesta to join the festivities. Velaris and the rest of Prythian are still in a state of recovery after the war against Hybern, and that delicate peace could overbalance at any time. In between overseeing the Illyrian war camps and rebuilding efforts around the city, Feyre and the Night Court are preparing for the coming holiday and enjoying the fact that they’re all still alive to celebrate it together.

Thoughts: I don’t usually care much for “additional content” type-things like novellas/short stories, even though I’m compelled to read them anyway, so A Court of Frost & Starlight is a pleasant surprise. It’s true that it’s low on plot–the biggest conflict is whether or not Nesta will show up for Solstice dinner–but after the abundance of plot, war, and general trauma in the last three books, that’s almost a relief. This book is a snapshot image of what life might be like for the Night Court now that they’ve managed to survive. They have a chance at a happy life together, and I enjoyed seeing that play out. It reads a bit like fanfiction, in the way that fanfiction often focuses on characters and their interactions rather than What Happens, and I mean that as a compliment

There isn’t a lot of magic or world-building to be had here either. In part, it’s because Velaris as the main setting has already been established, and it’s also because the characters don’t need to defend themselves every few pages. Other than the occasional flying or Rhys and Feyre talking through their mating bond, they’re mostly preoccupied with very human problems like what to get each other for Solstice (a task I take very seriously, so I can relate). I half-wish I’d waited to read it closer to Christmas, since it has so much winter atmosphere. It will make the perfect fluffy holiday read.

There’s a lot of attention on how the Night Court characters are dealing with the trauma of surviving a war. It’s a little hilarious to see Rhysand, the most powerful High Lord in history, acting like a lovesick teenager who can’t keep it in his pants. Feyre wonders whether it’s right to spend time painting, which helps her healing process, when there are so many other things that need to be done for her city. Tamlin and Nesta isolate themselves from everyone, and Cassian tries to save the Illyrians from thousands of years of ingrained bigotry. There’s much less attention given to Azriel, Elain, and Morrigan (my queen). We’re never granted chapters from their perspectives, and if there’s one thing I would change about this novella, it’s that we’d have more time/development with them. Alas, there are only so many pages. While I doubt it will be necessary to read it to understand the next book, it does serve as a nice bridge to the coming novels and a bow on top of Feyre and Rhysand’s finished story.

blog.name: lonely-book-lover
blog.title: The Every Day Life of a Nerdy Fangirl
blog.description: This is basically just my everyday thoughts on people, fandoms, etc. My main fandoms are Harry Potter, Percy Jackson (or anything written by Rick Riordon), Divergent, Hunger Games, Throne of Glass/A Court of Thorns and Roses, The Fault In Our Stars (or anything John Green related). This is mostly to just get my thoughts out but if anyone is actually reading this, I'd love for you to reach out to me! -Lonely-Book-Lover

blog.name: softlysaygoodbye
blog.title: My disorders are going to lose
blog.description: Welcome to my personal blog. I mainly post mental health and artsy things. I am an author, aspiring actress/musician, and public speaker. I am a twice published poet. Regarding education, I have acheived my High School Diploma, my Associates' Degree in Liberal Arts, and am graduating in May 2019 with my Bachelor's Degree in English. I am 20, and I DO NOT PROMOTE SUICIDE OR ANYTHING LIKE IT. THIS IS MY WAY OF VENTING & HELPING PEOPLE REALIZE THAT THEY ARE NOT ALONE IN THIS. I also do not own anything that isn't labeled with my url, myriah i. starrs, or myriah Iceillia starrs. (Trigger Warning)  Also, feel free to follow me on my other social media accounts. I love hearing from people. Pro-recovery blog. Recovering OSFED, Self-injury, Addict, Bipolar Disorder II, Anxiety, dissociative episodes, promiscuity, and suicidal ideation/near attempts. All types of abuse and bullying survivor. Former Seventh-day Adventist (cult survivor).

summary: Do you get that feeling where you have a fan theory and it's actually a positive one and you want to share it with everyone but...
body: Do you get that feeling where you have a fan theory and it’s actually a positive one and you want to share it with everyone but at the same time you don’t want to Jinx it but you can’t keep it in as well ? Just like Tom Holland struggles to keep the frog in his mouth.

reblog.comment: Do you get that feeling where you have a fan theory and it’s actually a positive one and you want to share it with everyone but at the same time you don’t want to Jinx it but you can’t keep it in as well ? Just like Tom Holland struggles to keep the frog in his mouth.

trail.content_raw: Do you get that feeling where you have a fan theory and it’s actually a positive one and you want to share it with everyone but at the same time you don’t want to Jinx it but you can’t keep it in as well ? Just like Tom Holland struggles to keep the frog in his mouth.
trail.content: Do you get that feeling where you have a fan theory and it’s actually a positive one and you want to share it with everyone but at the same time you don’t want to Jinx it but you can’t keep it in as well ? Just like Tom Holland struggles to keep the frog in his mouth.

summary: Queen of Shadows (Throne of Glass, #4) by Sarah J. Maas  The queen has returned.  Everyone Celaena Sardothien loves has been...
caption:
Queen of Shadows (Throne of Glass, #4) by Sarah J. Maas 

The queen has returned.

Everyone Celaena Sardothien loves has been taken from her. But she’s at last returned to the empire—for vengeance, to rescue her once-glorious kingdom, and to confront the shadows of her past…

She has embraced her identity as Aelin Galathynius, Queen of Terrasen. But before she can reclaim her throne, she must fight.

She will fight for her cousin, a warrior prepared to die for her. She will fight for her friend, a young man trapped in an unspeakable prison. And she will fight for her people, enslaved to a brutal king and awaiting their lost queen’s triumphant return.

The fourth volume in the New York Times bestselling series continues Celaena’s epic journey and builds to a passionate, agonizing crescendo that might just shatter her world.

This review contains spoilers!

I remember liking this book simply because of how much happens. I also really liked how the story is filled with so much action—-in all of the points of view we read from.

This book review is actually a re-read book review. So this time around my thoughts on Queen of Shadows are, admittedly, a little jumbled.

(Full review on Adele Is Reading)

tags: rhys is the most iconic high lord
summary: Remember that one time in ACOWAR when there was only one throne in the court of nightmares, so Rhys made Feyre sit on the...
body:
Remember that one time in ACOWAR when there was only one throne in the court of nightmares, so Rhys made Feyre sit on the throne, while he sat on the arm of it.

That was one Iconic scene, which will always make me love him. — We need more such iconic male characters in ya lit.

reblog.comment:
